status_message: Bradley Cooper's appearance on The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon last night happened to coincide with his 40th birthday, and to celebrate, the actor got the chance to show off his little-known musical talents. Click through to watch Cooper bust out an impeccable recreation of Neil Young's solo on "Down By the River" — on air guitar.
link_name: Watch Bradley Cooper Shred 'Down by the River' on Air Guitar

status_message: Welcome to the middle age of Marilyn Manson: More gym, less absinthe – and his best album in years. Click through for our stunning profile on the vampire of the Hollywood Hills.
link_name: Marilyn Manson: The Vampire of the Hollywood Hills

status_message: After months of speculation, Scott Weiland has revealed to us that 'Blaster,' his debut LP with backing band the Wildabouts, will be released in March and will be accompanied by a cross-country tour.
link_name: Scott Weiland Talks New 'Furry' Album 'Blaster,' Plots U.S. Tour

status_message: In the latest episode of Oprah Winfrey's 'Master Class' series, Jay Z talks about the role hip-hop music has played in diluting racial tensions in America. "I truly believe that racism is taught when you're young," Jay Z says. "So it's very difficult to teach racism when your kid looks up to Snoop Doggy Dogg." Click through to watch.
link_name: Jay Z: 'It's Difficult to Teach Racism When Your Kid Looks Up to Snoop Dogg'

status_message: With Courtney Love's opera debut scheduled for Thursday, the singer's performance of "All I Ever Wanted" from Todd Almond's pop opera 'Kansas City Choir Boy' has made it online. Click through to watch.
link_name: Watch Courtney Love's Opera Debut

status_message: January 11th finds the debut of Togetherness, an excellent new show brothers Jay and Mark Duplass wrote and directed about four overwhelmed adults, all of whom expected to have more of life's answers in their thirties than in their twenties. Click through for our feature on the Duplass brothers and their new HBO show.
link_name: How the Duplass Brothers Became Hollywood's Most Low-Key Power Players

status_message: On New Year's Eve, Kanye West and Paul McCartney dropped their collaboration "Only One" and a cyclone of "Who is Paul McCartney" activity soon took over Twitter. Let us soothe the worried minds of anyone trolled by these pranksters: Assuming that a teenager has been aware of pop culture in the last 10 years, click through for 14 reasons why there's really no excuse that millenials aren't mindful of Macca.
link_name: 14 Reasons Every Teenager Should Know Who Paul McCartney Is

status_message: Arizona's departing state superintendent of public education spent his last day of work targeting the Tucson Unified School District for violating the state's ban on ethnic studies. He focused on two music-related violations, the use of a Rage Against The Machine song in Mexican-American history and an introduction to hip-hop written by KRS-One in an English class taught from an African-American perspective.
link_name: Rage Against the Machine Defy Ethnic Studies Ban, Says Arizona Schools Chief

status_message: Every time a Kanye West fan buys an iTunes download, concert ticket or T-shirt, posts on his Facebook page, follows him on Twitter, views a YouTube video or streams a song on Spotify, all those clicks become valuable marketing data —and Universal Music wants to make money off that. Enter Global Music Data Alliance.
link_name: Follow Kanye on Twitter? Universal Wants to Make Money Off That

status_message: The prosecutor in the grand jury case against Darren Wilson, the police officer who shot and killed unarmed teenager Michael Brown in Ferguson, Missouri, is now the defendant in a lawsuit asking to lift the moratorium regarding the Wilson case.
link_name: Grand Juror Sues Ferguson Prosecutor Over Darren Wilson Moratorium

status_message: Selma Movie director Ava DuVernay spoke with us about the making of the film, her casting philosophy, MLK's legacy and why it helps to have Oprah on your set. "I wasn't interested in making a white-savior movie; I was interested in making a movie centered on the people of Selma," she says.
link_name: We Shall Overcome: Ava DuVernay on Making 'Selma'

status_message: Part addiction memoir and part first-person history of the era's alt-comedy boom, 'Silver Screen Fiend' is Patton Oswalt's attempt to detail his celluloid junkie phase and reconcile a four-year period spent in the dark. With that in mind, we asked Oswalt to share 10 films that influenced him most. From silent-horror flicks to, of course, 'Star Wars,' click through to see the movies that changed his life.
link_name: Patton Oswalt: My Life in 10 Movies

status_message: 2015 may not bring everything that 'Back to the Future II' promised it would: flying cars, self-lacing shoes, we don't see 'em happening over the next 12 months. But this year will definitely pack plenty of punch when it comes to cultural happenings. Click through for the smash albums, blockbuster movies and water-cooler TV shows to watch out for over the next year.
link_name: 2015 Preview: 68 Reasons to Love This Year

status_message: "I love the way you hurt me," Fall Out Boy frontman Patrick Stump sings on "Irresistible," an arena-pop anthem about deadly love. Click through to listen to the horn-driven track, which is included on the band's upcoming album, 'American Beauty/American Psycho.'
link_name: Fall Out Boy Explore Deadly Romance on Horn-Driven 'Irresistible'

status_message: Award season is once again upon us, a time when we celebrate all the best films of 2014… and all the movies we never want to see again. The annual Golden Raspberry Awards have announced their shortlist of contenders, with Seth McFarlane's western-comedy 'A Million Ways to Die in the West' leading the charge with eight potential nominations on the Razzies shortlist.
link_name: 'The Interview,' 'Sex Tape' Lead Razzies' Worst Film Shortlist

status_message: There is only one Wild Card team remaining in the NFL playoffs, and fittingly, it's the Baltimore Ravens. Are you ready to believe in the battle-tested birds?
link_name: Are You Ready to Believe in the Baltimore Ravens?

status_message: Danny Brown is hard at work on his fourth studio album – but he's also grinding away at another, more unusual, project: a Dr. Seuss-inspired children's book written for his 13-year-old daughter. "It's really about self-esteem in black girls," he says.
link_name: Danny Brown Writing Dr. Seuss-Styled Children's Book About Self-Esteem

status_message: The Panama Unit operated one of the most efficient drug-robbery rings in Texas, taking money from some dealers and traffickers while using their weapons and cars to rob others. Click though for the wild tale of cash, cocaine and corruption on the Texas border.
link_name: America's Dirtiest Cops: Cash, Cocaine and Corruption on the Texas Border

status_message: Taking parenting advice from one of the rockers in Guns N' Roses might not seem like a good idea, but for Duff McKagan we'll make an exception. The bassist is prepping his next book 'How to Be a Man (And Other Illusions),' which will share the life lessons he learned from his time with GNR and Velvet Revolver to getting sober and raising a family.
link_name: Duff McKagan Prepping Advice Book 'How to Be a Man'

status_message: The Black Keys drummer Patrick Carney suffered a dislocated shoulder Saturday on the island of Saint-Barthélemy after a giant wave slammed him into the ocean floor. Carney was reportedly rushed to the ER and administered anesthesia so doctors could reset his shoulder.
link_name: Black Keys Drummer Patrick Carney Dislocates Shoulder in Swimming Accident

status_message: North Korea has issued a response to the sanctions the U.S. Department of the Treasury levied on the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK) government following that country's involvement in the Sony cyber attack. "The persistent and unilateral action taken by the White House to slap 'sanctions' against the DPRK patently proves that it is still not away from inveterate repugnancy and hostility toward the DPRK," said North Korea's state-run Central News Agency.
link_name: 'The Interview': North Korea Responds to U.S. Sanctions

status_message: Stuart Scott, longtime ESPN SportsCenter anchor and a pioneering force in the field of sportscasting, passed away Sunday morning after a long battle with cancer. He was 49. Click through to see how the hip-hop community has paid tribute to the man who coined the phrase "Cool as the other side of the pillow."
link_name: ESPN Anchor Stuart Scott Dead at 49

status_message: From unreleased Bob Dylan song lyrics to Willie Nelson's braids to John Lennon's "Paperback Writer" guitar, it's been an interesting few months for rock memorabilia on the auction block. That trend looks to continue in 2015 as a few more rare music-related items will go to a winning bidder: Elvis Presley's private planes and a suede vest worn by Janis Joplin.
link_name: Elvis' Private Planes, Janis Joplin's Vest Hit the Auction Block

status_message: They Might Be Giants have brought back their legendary Dial-A-Song project in a big way in 2015, reactivating their phone line to premiere new music each week. Click through to find out TMBF's new phone number and hear their new track "I Wasn't Listening."
link_name: They Might Be Giants Resurrect Dial-A-Song in 2015

status_message: Kid Rock will release his 10th studio album 'First Kiss' on February 24th, and in the lead-up to the new LP, the rocker is not holding back in interviews, providing his earnest opinion on a variety of subjects regardless of who it might offend.
link_name: Kid Rock: 'I Don't FaceTweet'

status_message: PJ Harvey's much-anticipated follow-up to 2011's Mercury Prize-winning 'Let England Shake' will shatter the line between a live album and a studio LP thanks to a living art exhibit called 'Recording in Progress'. For four weeks, Harvey, her band, producers and engineers will occupy a glass-encased studio in the Somerset House in London to record Harvey's upcoming album as museumgoers watch as the singer creates the songs from scratch.
link_name: PJ Harvey to Record New Studio Album in Front of Live Audience

status_message: For hip hop fans, author Brian Coleman is doing the Lord's work. In 2005, the writer and historian self-published 'Rakim Told Me', an oral history of some of the genre's most influential albums told by its creators. Coleman would expand on 'Rakim' with 2007's 'Check the Technique' and recently released Volume 2 of the popular series that's become a must-read for rap geeks wanting the inside story to their favorite albums.
link_name: The Inside Story of Naughty by Nature's 'O.P.P.'

status_message: After Kanye West unveiled his Paul McCartney-featuring ballad "Only One" on New Year's Day, a spokesperson for the rapper said the track was the first of "what has become a prolific musical collaboration between these two legendary artists." According to singer/producer Ty Dolla $ign, who provided background vocals on "Only One," the next Paul McCartney/Kanye West song is "gonna drop soon" and it will also feature Rihanna.
link_name: Ty Dolla $ign Hints at Kanye/McCartney Collaboration With Rihanna

status_message: After confirming that North Korea was behind the crippling Sony cyber attack, President Barack Obama promised to levy a "proportional and appropriate" response for the hack. The U.S. Department of the Treasury revealed the first wave of that action Friday, issuing sanctions against the government of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK) as well as some DPRK-controlled businesses.
link_name: U.S. Treasury Imposes Sanctions Against North Korea Following Sony Cyber Attack

status_message: Billy Joel was honored with the Library of Congress' Gershwin Prize for Popular Song in a star-studded celebration that aired Friday night on PBS, and among the tribute's many highlights was host Kevin Spacey accompanying Joel on "Piano Man," with the 'House of Cards' actor showing off his impressive harmonica skills.
link_name: Watch Kevin Spacey Perform 'Piano Man' With Billy Joel

status_message: Mark Wahlberg generously tossed in the big blind to help us kick off a new video series, "Research and Destroy," in which actors and actresses discuss how they prep for roles. With a deck of cards in hand, click through to watch Wahlberg discuss his process for 'The Gambler.'
link_name: Watch Mark Wahlberg Destroy at Blackjack and Talk Shop on 'The Gambler'

status_message: Green Day's mud-caked set at Woodstock '94 was a crucial moment in the group's long history, but to Billie Joe Armstrong's mother Ollie - who witnessed her son pulling his pants down, throwing mud at fans and chanting obscenities on live television - it was nothing but a profound embarrassment. Click through to watch the band's epic mud fight.
link_name: Flashback: Green Day Get Muddy and Violent at Woodstock '94

status_message: Anna Jane Joyner is evangelical royalty: Her father founded a megachurch with 1,000 congregations. But Anna Jane had a political come-to-Jesus moment while at UNC, and today she's the millennial face of a national movement that seeks to convince America's evangelicals that biblical tenets are compatible with environmentalism. But can a 29-year-old Christian activist make conservatives care about climate change?
link_name: Can a Christian Make Conservatives Care About Climate Change?

status_message: Nicki Minaj has turned into one of hip-hop's most consistently entertaining video artists, filling her clips with oddball concepts, colorful costumes and eye-popping effects. Click through to see the 10 best from her first half-decade of stardom.
link_name: Vid It It On'em: Nicki Minaj's 10 Best Clips

status_message: Cameras were rolling at Seattle's Kingdome on June 10th, 1976 for the Wings concert film 'Rockshow.' Click through to watch the performance of "Band on the Run" from that night.
link_name: Flashback: Wings Touch Down In America in 1976

status_message: U2 singer Bono posted a 6,000-word A to Z summation of 2014 to the band's website, revealing that the massive bike injury he suffered last year may prevent him from ever playing guitar again. He also gave his thoughts on Kanye West, Jimmy Fallon, capitalism and the only criticism of 'Songs of Innocence' that "stung."
link_name: Bono: 'I May Never Play Guitar Again'

status_message: Taylor Swift, Thom Yorke, Prince and The Beatles are some of the last major acts who won't stream. Click through to find out why they are among the biggest holdouts in digital music.
link_name: Islands in the Stream: The 10 Biggest Holdouts in Digital Music

status_message: In an age of surprise albums and lengthy hype-building mixtapes, Nicki Minaj embarked on a slow-burning campaign for her third album, The Pinkprint, which ended up encompassing nearly the entirety of 2014. Click through for a rundown of 19 tracks that promoted the album's release without ever appearing on it.
link_name: 19 Nicki Minaj Songs That Paved the Road to 'The Pinkprint'

status_message: Peter Travers has a message for Academy voters: Attention must be paid to the actors who did incredible work in 2014 but aren't getting the buzz they deserve. Click through for his open letter to the Oscars and see his picks for underrated performances.
link_name: Open Letter to the Oscars: Don't Forget These Great 2014 Performances

status_message: ELVIS PRESLEY's career was in a pretty remarkable place when he hit the road for an American arena tour in April of 1972. Documentary filmmakers joined him for the tour to shoot 'Elvis on Tour,' which would go on to win a Golden Globe. Click through to watch a "Bridge Over Troubled Water" cover from the April 14th show at the Greensboro Coliseum in North Carolina.
link_name: Flashback: Elvis Presley Sings 'Bridge Over Troubled Water' in 1972

status_message: So maybe Merle Haggard didn't smoke marijuana in Muskogee or take trips on LSD, but that certainly didn't stop country's greats from trading a shot of Tennessee brown for a toke of Colorado green — and singing about it, too. From Willie Nelson's weed to Johnny Cash's coke, click through for 15 of the greatest country songs about drugs.
link_name: Country's 15 Highest Drug Odes

status_message: He's been called a master of hip cinematic heartbreak who deals in worlds as shiny and perfect as a Christmas ornament — or, put more charitably, a virtuoso at making pathos both wrenching and witty in a idiosyncratic, individual style. You always know when you're watching a Wes Anderson film; the symmetrical compositions and deep-cut soundtracks are a dead giveaway. Click through for a tour of the highly stylized world of Anderson's movies.
link_name: Wes World: The Cut-to-Fit Universe of Wes Anderson

status_message: Things are going really fast for Fall Out Boy right now: They are in the middle of a run of playing 15 radio-station festivals in just 20 days.  The band's new single has racked up more than 30 million plays on Spotify and they just finished their sixth album, 'American Beauty/American Psycho,' due later this month. Click through for our feature on how one of the biggest bands of the '00s became unlikely chart heroes.
link_name: How Fall Out Boy Beat the Odds and Became Top 40 Survivors

status_message: Last night, Kanye West unveiled "Only One," a minimal, poignant new track featuring Paul McCartney on keyboard.
link_name: Hear Paul McCartney and Kanye West's Emotional Ballad 'Only One'

status_message: Nicki Minaj is known for writing the sharpest lyrics in rap. Click through to revisit her 10 fiercest disses.
link_name: Gritty in Pink: Nicki Minaj's 10 Fiercest Disses

status_message: "Whistlers and Jugglers," written by prolific songwriter, author and cartoonist Shel Silverstein, appeared on Waylon Jennings' 1978 I've Always Been Crazy LP. Now, his son Shooter has covered the track for a new compilation. Click through to listen to the track, which is reminiscent of Pink Floyd.
link_name: Hear Shooter Jennings Channel Pink Floyd in Waylon Cover
